Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60VX-8MP1-DXH2-62KN-00000-00Hess Corp at JPMorgan US AllStars Conference (Virtual) - Final2020-09-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:58ZLexisNexis091520a13396848.748Hess Corp at JPMorgan US AllStars Conference (Virtual) - Final

Corporate Participants

* John B. Hess

Hess Corporation - CEO & Director

Conference Call Participants

* Arun Jayaram

JPMorgan Chase & Co, Research Division - Senior Equity Research Analyst

Presentation

ARUN JAYARAM, SENIOR EQUITY RESEARCH ANALYST, JPMORGAN CHASE & CO, RESEARCH DIVISION: Good afternoon. Welcome to today's fireside chat investor event with Hess at the JPMorgan All Stars Conference. My name is Arun Jayaram, Head of U.S. E&P Research at JPMorgan. We are delighted to welcome John Hess to the 2020 All Stars Conference, which includes some of the highest blue-chip stocks and management teams in the U.S. So the bar for an invite is high. We also want to thank CLO, Greg Hill; CFO, John Rielly; and Jay Wilson, in Investor Relations, for participating in today's All Stars Conference.

In June, we did publish a series of week-long deep dives during JPMorgan's Hess Week, which articulated our positive stamps on the name. Please ping me if you want a copy of the report or want to set up a call on the stock.

With some of the formalities out of the way, I would like to welcome you, John, to the All Stars Conference. John, how are you?

JOHN B. HESS, CEO & DIRECTOR, HESS CORPORATION: Okay, Arun. I hope you and your family are well and everybody on the call are well as well. But thank you for the opportunity to speak at this conference and very much appreciate your hard work on the company and your support of the company.

ARUN JAYARAM: Great. Great. And again, thanks, again, for your important time. I know there's a lot of things between COVID and all those things that we think about. And so we do obviously appreciate you giving us some of your valuable time to meet with investors in Europe today.

So John, I have divided this topic -- or today's presentation into a series of topics to maybe help frame the discussion. And so I just thought I would maybe jump off and talk about the macro and how do you see the macro environment for oil playing out, assuming an L-, U- or V-shaped recovery.

Questions and Answers

JOHN B. HESS: Thanks, Arun. And we look at it really through 3 lenses: demand, supply and inventories. In terms of demand, we think we're in a V-shaped recovery. April demand in the world was down 21 million barrels a day, probably a little bit more than that out of a total global demand of 100 million barrels a day. So the most severe demand drop we've ever experienced, that U.S. and Europe shut down, 4 billion people basically were in quarantine, and the economy of the world came to a stop.

Today, demand loss has recovered to about 7 million barrels a day. I know the IEA just came out today and said it was 8 million barrels a day, but close enough. And of that 7 million barrel-a-day drop, about 5 million barrels a day is jet fuel. People still aren't flying. A million barrels a day is gasoline. People are driving, not using public transportation. And heating oil, as the industrial sector comes back, heating oil is down about -- or gas oil is down about a million barrels a day.

And while demand continues to increase or grow, it is stalling out right now. And why is it stalling out? Why has the market gone down about $5 a barrel? Part of that probably has to do with the financial markets taking a pause after the Labor Day and risk all, but part of it is also we're in a shoulder month for oil demand in September, also in October. Refinery runs go down. So the bid in the market is not quite as strong. But we see demand strengthening almost 3 million barrels a day between now and the end of the year as the winter approaches and refinery runs go up. And I think the key to next year is going to be the vaccine. Some people call it the vaccine trade, meaning when the vaccine's out, we think by talking to the different pharmaceutical companies, there's a high likelihood that the vaccine will start being distributed at the beginning of the year. We see jet fuel demand coming back, and probably, demand next year will be down on the year, maybe 2 million barrels a day. I know that's a risk, maybe that doesn't happen, but that's how we see the world going forward on demand.

In terms of supply, where demand is a V-shaped recovery, we see supply being a U-shaped recovery, meaning supply being stickier to respond to the shocks that COVID has created in the economy. In the U.S., the rig count has gone down to 254 rigs running. That compares to over 1,000 over a year ago. And as a consequence, production declines are taking effect, even though a lot of the shut-ins in the U.S. have come back, with oil being closer to $40 a barrel TI.

We see supply in the U.S. for crude and condensate going from 12.8 million barrels a day at the end of the year, to 10.8 million barrels a day today. And we see that number as being sticky until the rig count increases. If anything, we're more worried that maybe that number is going to be lower next year as long as the rig count is as low as it is.

In terms of long-cycle projects, we look at projects that are over $1 billion or more when they're authorized. That number is about 7. That's come down by a factor of 100%, probably from 15 to 7. And that long-cycle pipeline outside of Guyana is pretty much running on empty. One of the signs that the disinvestment in long cycle is going on is our own Gulf of Mexico here in the United States. 15 years ago, 8,800 blocks were leased to oil companies. Today, that number is 2,500. So there just aren't the inventory of drillable prospects out there because a lot of people have withdrawn either to the Permian or now just conserving cash. Obviously, our company is contrasted in that, in that we bought 60 blocks in the last 5 years. We have refilled our cupboard, if you will, for $120 million of some very high-return opportunities.

I think the third point on supply is OPEC+, the historic agreement that was made in April. Now their production is down about 7.7 million barrels a day. Compliance is high, probably running at about 95%. The OPEC+ countries are suffering, not just the oil producers like ourselves. Saudi itself, probably with a price drop, has lost revenue of about $100 billion this year. Their financial reserves are about $450 billion. So that's a 25% decrease in 1 year. That's not sustainable. They've got an economy and society to run. And they're feeling the pinch. Russia's feeling the pinch, oil producers are. So we think there's a reasonable chance that the compliance that has been had in the last several months will continue in the future.

So that's sort of the supply update, U-shaped recovery, demand, V-shaped recovery. All of this, when you put it together, it comes back to inventories. And due to COVID and the demand shock, global inventories built a surplus of about 1 billion barrels of oil. We think that number has gone down about 200 million barrels since April as demand has been greater than supply. While we're sort of stalling out now as demand accelerates into the end of the year, we think there will be a draw of another 250 million barrels. And basically, the balance will come in next year in 2021, probably at midyear, where we get to pre-COVID inventory levels. So with that, we do think prices will firm. They have to firm to incentivize investment, but also, they will be at a level of an equilibrium price that still will work for consumers.

So the market is in the process of recovering. But because the overhang was so severe, it's going to take some time to get to the finish line, at pre-COVID levels of inventory.

ARUN JAYARAM: Great. John, you have a diversified kind of portfolio. So you have -- really looking for your perspective on this answer. But who do you think, from a stock market perspective, will win in the next cycle? We hope that inventories get, call it, rebalanced by the middle part of next year. But do you think that we'll be in the Catbird speed, see short-cycle shale producers, obviously, you have a large Bakken footprint, or long-cycle companies like Hess, who are investing in some of these great projects like Guyana?

JOHN B. HESS: I think it's the low-cost producer that wins. We have a long-dated growing resource with decreasing breakeven costs going to $40 a barrel Brent or lower by mid-decade. And I remember being at a London energy conference a couple of years ago, and a number of the E&P executives of the major oil companies were on stage in a session. And the question was asked, what's better, short cycle or long cycle. And I think the answer is not either/or, but and. It's the best rocks for the best returns. And we feel our company, with Guyana, probably the largest oil discovery in the last 20 years, world-class resource with low breakeven costs, our position in the Bakken where we've practiced lean manufacturing to keep driving our cost of development and completion down and our productivity up with plug-and-perf, we think we're in a strong position relative to our competitors to provide industry-leading cash flow growth.

One of the things we put in our investor presentation is Page 19, to show our cash flow growth over the next 3 years using third-party estimates to kind of companies as yourself, providing the estimates of our cash flow growth using your prices, consensus estimate on volumes and costs. And what you can see in that chart is our cash flow compounds out to 2022 at 10% a year, where the median of our peers actually decreases 10% a year. So then we actually raise the bar and say, how do we compare in cash flow growth versus the S&P. And again, our 10% growth is competitive with big tech, with big pharma and big consumer companies. So I think our value proposition is unique. We're growing our resource, we're decreasing our cost to a breakeven of $40 Brent by mid-decade, and what that allows is our cash flow to compound, not just to 2022, but out to 2025 and beyond. And again, it's about the best rocks and the best returns in our portfolio.

ARUN JAYARAM: Great. John, the next big topic I wanted to talk to you about is ESG. ESG topics have been at the forefront of shareholders' resolutions at energy companies' annual meetings. What's your view on the evolving sustainability preferences of shareholders? And do you see a transatlantic divide on the issue between European shareholders and U.S. holders?

JOHN B. HESS: Well, we believe that climate change is real and probably the greatest scientific challenge of the 21st century. Our company's purpose is to be the most trusted energy partner in the world. It's fundamental to how we do business, where values drive value, and climate change is at the center of this. So we, on the one hand, want to provide the world with safe, affordable and reliable energy, but on the other hand, reduce our carbon footprint and contribute to the technology and scientific breakthroughs that are needed to respond to the global challenge of climate change.

We've been doing a sustainability report for 23 years, way before it was in vogue. So it is part of our core values. And we're honored and our teams are honored, that worked so hard on this, to be an industry leader in ESG performance as well as disclosure. Over the past 12 years, we've reduced our Scope 1 and 2 emissions by 60%. We're also supporting research of the Salk Institute for nature-based solutions to grow plants, with longer roots, wider roots and suberin in them, a key element, to allow crops to store and sequester carbon where potentially billions of tons per year can be taken out of the atmosphere. So our company is doing its part.

You talk about the Atlantic divide. I certainly think some of the forward-thinking in Europe about addressing climate change is coming to the United States. It's manifest in different ways. Certainly, investors, it's a topic that we talk about in virtually every meeting, whether it's a European investor or an American investor. But I think there are 2 key points to this. One is being climate-literate, but the other is being energy-literate. And we looked to the IEA to provide the information to try to give us the idea of understanding what are the scenarios going forward to how you balance the need for the world having to have 30% more energy in 2040 as populations grow, living standards grow, mobility needs increase and yet reduce CO2 footprint by 80%, if not 100%, during the time period up to, let's say, to 2040.

And in the most rigorous scenario of sustainable development, where all the pledges of the Paris climate accord are met, oil and gas is still 47% of the mix in 2040. So I think engaging shareholders, it's important to hear what they have to say. But we in industry also have a narrative to say, the world needs more oil and gas, but the world also needs to reduce its carbon footprint. How can we have cost-effective solutions to deal with this? There's no simple answer, and it's going to -- the energy transition is going to take time. But I think Hess is uniquely positioned because we're going to have a low breakeven of $40 a barrel Brent or less. So in any scenario, I think we come out to win.

ARUN JAYARAM: And just maybe to add to that last question on how is Hess positioned from an ESG perspective. Can you talk about, obviously, Guyana is going to be a big part of Hess' future kind of story. How does that project kind of position, that's obviously offshore, from an ESG kind of perspective?

JOHN B. HESS: Absolutely. Well, just last week, we announced our Redtail-1 and Yellowtail-2 discoveries, bringing total discoveries on the Stabroek Block in Guyana to 18, which brings our discovered resource to greater than 8 billion barrels of oil equivalent since 2015. In addition to that, we still see multibillion barrels of exploration potential remaining. Most of the discoveries today are at 15,000 feet vertical depth, which is shallow relative to the Gulf of Mexico, by the way. And we're starting to see -- we've had 2 penetrations in what's called the Santonian at 18,000 feet. And correlating our well logs to our seismic, we see a lot of running room, not just at 15,000 feet, the Campanian, but also at 18,000 feet of the Santonian. So we're still in early innings in Guyana, continues to get bigger and better.

Liza Phase 1, our first ship, is ramping up to its capacity of 120,000 barrels a day, where we think it will be at the end of the month. Liza Phase 2, 220,000 barrels a day. Remember, we have 30% of interest in all of these assets. That ship should be onstream by the beginning of 2022. It's currently in the yard in Singapore being outfitted with top sides.

The Payara ship, which is the third ship, which has been delayed in terms of getting a production license, in part because of COVID, in part because of a contested election in Guyana which has been resolved, we have been in constant communication as a joint venture with the new government to get the production license approved. We're optimistic that there's a few outstanding issues, mostly technical in nature, that they will be addressed so that we'll have that production license for another 220,000 barrel-a-day ship by the end of September. And the 6- to 12-month delay that Exxon -- the operators talked about, that have potential delays to that ship coming on production, that no longer will be the case and will be back on track with its original time line.

The important thing about the Redtail and Yellowtail discoveries is it really shows the greater Yellowtail area being a large resource, and it's a high-quality resource, Brent-based type of crude, lighter crude and expansive, high production rates, and we're doing the predevelopment work now to make that the fourth ship. We don't want to get ahead of Exxon or the government. We have to get the development work done. But we're relatively optimistic that, that will be the fourth ship, of about 220,000 barrels a day. Then the Uaru area nearby potentially could be the fifth ship. Turbot could be the fifth ship. And when you add those 2 together, that actually gets you to 6 ships. And we still have Hammerhead out there that's a heavier accumulation, that will be commercial one day. So there's the potential for 7 ships.

So my point in saying this, right now, we're just talking about at least 5 ships and 750,000 barrels a day capacity by 2026. So I would take the over on that based upon what I'm saying. So when people talk about when is Guyana going to plateau, we have the visibility for production growth well beyond the 750,000 barrels a day based upon the resource that's been discovered. We're just focused on investing in the lowest-cost opportunities with the highest returns, and the sequencing keeps getting optimized.

Another point there on Guyana is Liza Phase 1 has a breakeven for a 10% return at $35 Brent. And the second ship, Liza Phase 2, has a breakeven of $25 Brent. So even in a carbon-constrained world, these barrels will provide low-cost energy for many years to come and be a great return for our shareholders.

ARUN JAYARAM: Great, John. I know Guyana is going to be part of the answer to this next question, or I would assume. But one of the things that we talked about leading into the conference is the fact how energy stocks have dramatically lagged the broader market. In the U.S., it saddens me to say this, but we're now 3% of the entire market. This is a conference that includes, I think, over 60 of some of the best companies, management team stocks, cash flow stories in the whole market. So what do you think really differentiates Hess from the rest of the E&P or broader energy group? And why should generalist investors do work on Hess?

JOHN B. HESS: We had put out a financial outlook in our last Investor Day about 1.5 years ago and basically showed the growth of our assets on the top line at 10%, but the growth of our cash flow at 20%. And any business that has cash flow growth growing greater than the top line is a company you want to own, whether it's in the energy industry or outside the energy industry. That is our long-term strategy. It's still intact. Obviously with COVID, we took a timeout this year just to preserve our cash position so we would preserve the long-term value of our assets.

But what's unusual about Hess' portfolio, it's balanced between short cycle and long cycle. But right now, 3 of our 4 key assets, the Bakken, the Gulf of Mexico and Malaysia, are cash engines. In the next 2 to 3 years, Guyana becomes a cash engine. So Hess is in a unique position, unlike shale companies, that we're able to invest in the business, grow the business, but also generate compounding cash flow and free cash flow such that, that we not only can grow our resource but also grow cash returns to our shareholders. And that balance is unusual in the business, and it's driven by the low-cost breakeven that we have.

ARUN JAYARAM: Great. John, the next topic I wanted to talk to you about is COVID. Could you talk about some of the actions that you and the Hess management team have taken in response to COVID-19? And any lingering impacts of the virus on your operations as we sit here today?

JOHN B. HESS: Well, when we were faced with the challenge from COVID, we came up with 3 key strategic priorities: preserve cash, preserve capability and preserve the long-term value of our assets. And preserving cash, we entered the third quarter with $1.6 billion of cash. We've hedged over 80% of our crude production this year, 130 a day of WTI, $55, with put options, and 20 a day of Brent at $60 with put options. And that obviously has given us a cash cushion that has helped us quite a bit during this transition to where we become cash flow and free cash flow positive. We also reduced our CapEx, from $3 billion to $1.9 billion, and reduced our cash cost, $265 million, as well.

At the same time, we're in a long lead time business. We wanted to protect our capability. So instead of taking our Bakken rigs to 0 from 6, we took it to 1. So lean manufacturing and innovation that we have in our organization is perpetuated. The Bakken continues to perform well. We set a target of 200,000 barrels a day equivalent production for the year at the end of the year. We met it at the middle of the year. We also set a target for drilling and completion cost per well of $6 million from $7 million a year ago. We've already gone through that $6 million mark, so it's top quartile performance with our plug-and-perf completions. But we also wanted to protect our capability in exploration, which is a technologically advanced business, really capable professionals that use AI and a lot of computer tools in our seismic model. So that was an important capability to protect as well, which we have, because we believe, to get to your point of what makes us different, we still believe in exploration because it's the best way to find low-cost reserves that could create a lot of value.

And then the third priority is protecting the long-term value of our assets. I talked about Guyana in that regard. Both for us and Exxon, it's our best investment. And while we cut everything else out, that's something we're going to protect and see it through to where it becomes a free cash flow generator.

I think another key point, Arun, on our cash flow growth and growing cash flow to invest in the business but also return cash to shareholders, we are going to get to an inflection point between the second ship in Guyana coming on in 2022 and the third ship coming on in 2023, where our company starts to be free cash flow positive on a sustainable basis. It's about the durability of our cash flows, which I think are distinctive, not just in oil, but also in industry overall in the S&P.

The priorities for that cash are going to be to reduce our debt first, that $1 billion we took on to bridge us of a term loan, I think it was the only 3-year term loan that was granted to oil and gas companies when COVID hit, we want to pay that debt off. But once we get beyond that and are generating free cash, the priority is to return the majority of that cash to our shareholders, first, by increasing the dividend and then by complementing that with opportunistic share repurchases. And I think that value proposition of growing our assets, but also growing our cash returns to shareholders, are going to appeal not just to oil and gas investors, but also those S&P investors as well.

ARUN JAYARAM: Got it. John, you stole my next question, but maybe -- it's such an important topic. I want to come back to it. One of the biggest questions I face as an E&P analyst is, really, it's such a huge topic. The elephant in the room is this long-term investment framework. So maybe just to ask the question in maybe a different way is how do you balance investing in this great project in Guyana versus that desire to return cash to shareholders? And how do you think about that framework over a longer period of time?

JOHN B. HESS: Because Guyana is a world-class resource with these low breakevens that I talked about, Guyana itself becomes a cash engine, probably 2022, 2023, depending upon oil price. So all 4 key assets of Hess, the Bakken, the Gulf of Mexico, Malaysia and Guyana, are going to be growing. So we're going to have enough cash flow to invest in the business, and that will be between $1.9 billion and $2.5 billion, depending upon where the Bakken is and where we are in the time lines of Guyana versus the $1.9 billion we're investing now. And still, we will have free cash flow on top of that to return cash to shareholders.

So it's because of the portfolio of high quality, low cost of supply investments that we have that we're able to invest in the business but also compound cash flow growth, allowing us to return the majority of our free cash flow as cash returns to our shareholders while we're still growing the business. The challenge with shale companies, quite frankly, is they're very capital-intensive, and it takes years before they become free cash flow positive.

And if they're going to run their companies, which they should to be free cash flow positive, their top line growth has to be impeded. Because we have superior investment opportunities with higher returns and lower costs, we're able to grow the resource, grow our production and at the same time, grow our free cash flow. And it's, again, the portfolio of the best rocks for the best returns, we have that in our company. And that's why we stayed in the long-cycle business because we thought that just short-cycle shale would eventually become a mature business and have capital pressures on it that we're able to overcome because we have a superior investment portfolio between short cycle and long cycle.

ARUN JAYARAM: Yes. John, one of the questions I get from investors is you and Exxon have had to make some adjustments to capital just given COVID, a lower oil price environment, this -- call it this -- and Phase 3 just because of the election cycle in Guyana. But the question is, has the Exxon-Hess consortium, are you still adjusting your long-term capital in any ways that would impact perhaps the timing, let's say, you get government approval for Phase 3, but are you still investing appropriately in Guyana? Are you going to bring a fifth rig next year? That's the question I get from investors.

JOHN B. HESS: Sure. No. Neil Chapman, I think, on Exxon's last quarterly call, has said this, and we certainly say it as well. Whatever capital Guyana needs it's going to get because it's such a high return and enables you to become a cash engine and a free cash flow generator. So you're going to cut everything else off before you start that.

Having said that, when COVID hit, for COVID reasons, and also election reasons, first, we were worried about Payara being delayed. Now I'm pretty confident that it will stay on its original track. Remember, we've already constructed with SBM the hull for the third ship, which is Payara. But the one area that actually was delayed some was the timing for the fourth and fifth ship coming on. Originally, we said that we were going to have 5 -- at least 5 ships on, producing 750,000 barrels a day by 2025. Now that number is 2026. But actually, the timeout has worked to our advantage, where both we have found higher-quality resource in the greater Yellowtail area. So it would actually be a lower cost of development than we originally anticipated at Hammerhead, and it will also be a larger development at 220,000 barrels a day versus 140 a day at Hammerhead.

So we actually are creating value in that interim. So while we may be delayed, we're actually going to have a higher NBV and a higher cash return because of the change in ships. I think the other point is we have found, to get to your point on exploration in the fifth rig, because we are going -- we currently have 4 rigs in theater, basically 2 working on development drilling for the 2 ships and 2 working on exploration and appraisal. Once we have Payara, we're going to have to take one of those ships and have development drilling for Payara. So we think, to get after the exploration and appraisal work we have, we will need to bring the fifth ship in theater. So plans are underway to move forward on that.

ARUN JAYARAM: Yes. The last question kind of on this capital allocation investment kind of question set is can you talk -- maybe delve a little bit deeper on how the company is managing this low-price environment and some of the outspend until you get ship 2 on phase. And just if you could also address the sanctity of the dividend. I know you preserved the dividend in the tip of this downcycle, this vicious downcycle, but I wanted to get your thoughts on both of those 2 questions.

JOHN B. HESS: Well, it gets to that first strategic priority of preserving cash. Any time there's been a financial crisis or oil crisis, you have to have a strong cash position. You never run out of cash. I know it's a truism, but in times of stress, it's especially profound. And we entered the third quarter with $1.6 billion of cash. We got the 3-year term loan, $1 billion as well. We have the hedges. We also had a VLCC strategy, where other people were shutting in shale production in the United States, because we've invested in the midstream. And we also have a great commercial team. We chartered 3 VLCCs, so we didn't have to shut-in production and we could move oil out at Brent-based pricing. The first VLCC, we've actually already sold in at a Brent premium price into China. That ship should be offloaded before the end of September.

The other 2 ships we should sell during the fourth quarter. So it's all about preserving cash. To your point, yes, we have an outspend next year. People say, John, don't call it an outspend. It's an investment program in a high-return project in Guyana. That's the case, but it's still an outspend.

So how do we think about that? It's keeping the capital tight. We reduced our capital from $3 billion going into this year to $1.9 billion, a lot of that for Guyana, cutting back on the Bakken as well. Prices are here. You can assume that will be the number for next year in the range. We'll announce that in January. So keeping the first strings tight until that second ship to come on is important.

In addition to that, we will be a price-taker at the end of the year to put more hedging on. We will use puts. As you know, options have time value and as well as volatility value. So right now, putting options on would be expensive. We'll wait until the end of the year, where they are less expensive, whatever the prices it is. If the oil market firms a little better, we're putting better insurance on. But we're not doing it to call price. We're doing it to protect the downside, so we can get to that second ship. So all of these are steps to keep our financial strength.

And the one other thing, Arun, we still have some noncore assets. I can't be specific about which ones that we are advanced in considering selling. That will fortify our cash position more. So we're taking all the steps to keep the cash position strong. So even if oil prices are low next year, even if we have an economic downturn next year, we still are going to be strong as a company going into 2022 when that second ship in Guyana comes on at 60,000 barrels a day with a breakeven of $25 Brent.

ARUN JAYARAM: Great. John, you touched upon this earlier, but I did want to maybe elaborate, the next time it's going to be Guyana. Let's start with Liza Phase 1. You got that on production early. And like any large industrial project in the early phases, you're just going to go through some commissioning and some teething issues that you troubleshoot. I know that you have a built one. And then you'll have that same kind of design on a go-forward basis. But can you give us a little bit of an update on how production, how the reservoir has been performing? And any thoughts on getting to that peak plateau rate, which I think The Street is modeling in the 120 kbd range on a gross basis and you're 30% of that?

JOHN B. HESS: Yes. We've had some short-term start-up problems, debottlenecking problems on the ship. It has nothing to do with the reservoir. It has to do with the gas compression and gas handling system on the ship. Some of it has to do with metallurgy. Some of it has to do with COVID to get the experts in to fix it. SBM is obviously overall responsible, but Exxon is the project manager on this. Efforts are underway to get it fixed. It's taken a little bit longer for the reasons that I mentioned, getting materials in place as well as people in place. It's taken a little bit longer. We thought it would get to the 120 a-day nameplate in August. Now it looks like it will be the end of September. But it's a short-term issue. Exxon is all over it. It's going to get fixed to get to that peak rate of 120 a day. So we're getting very close to that finish line.

I think what's important to note, this is a short-term mechanical problem that has to do with the top sides, operating system on the ship. It has nothing to do with the quality of the reservoir. The wells have been performing at or above capacity, very high flow rates. When people talk about EURs, estimated ultimate recovery, in shale wells, they talk about 1 million barrels. If you're really lucky, maybe 2 million barrels, right? But normally, it's a million barrels.

When you're talking about EURs in Liza Phase 1, it's 50 million to 60 million barrels. So it's just a whole another quantum of productivity and high-quality performance in terms of production rates as well as recovery rates. The reservoir, if anything, is better than we anticipated. And we're going to be doing a drill stem test both on Redtail-1 and Yellowtail-2 to really finalize and evaluate the quality of that reservoir for the fourth ship. So it's a -- top side, it's a mechanical issue, it will be fixed, but the reservoir itself is some of the best-performing reservoirs in the world.

ARUN JAYARAM: Yes. The other question I get from investors is just Liza Phase 2. We obviously have COVID. If you think about the shipyards and that, can you provide us maybe an updated time line on your current expectations around timing for Phase 2?

JOHN B. HESS: Yes. Phase 2, while there were some slowdowns in the yard because of COVID in Singapore, the Keppel Shipyard, Exxon had been doing a masterful job of running ahead of schedule. So there was some cushion in the system, and thank God there was. So Exxon is still very, very confident about being able to bring that ship on with production and all the subsea and drilling campaigns that have to be done over 2 seasons. We're still looking at early 2022. So the original target is still the target for first production of that 220,000 barrels a day.

ARUN JAYARAM: Great. John, the market has recently digested some good drill bit news from the Exxon-Hess consortium. You just talked about Redtail, success there as well as at the deeper interval at Yellowtail-2. The key incoming question from the buy side is whether these new 2 discoveries that you guys have announced, does this change your view of the peak production capacity of Guyana or just extend that plateau rate forever -- the length of, call it, that plateau rate?

JOHN B. HESS: First and foremost, it extends and grows the peak production capacity of Guyana. That's why I said, when we say it's at least 5 ships and at least 750,000 barrels a day by 2026, we can see well past that with a much higher number. Obviously, we have more appraisal work to do to define what the fifth ship is, potentially what the sixth ship is, potentially what the seventh ship is. So first and foremost, it extends that and grows the peak.

In addition to that, however, it also will extend the plateau because we're finding a lot more oil, both at 15,000 feet and hopefully, it's 18,000 feet. So Guyana will be generating cash flow for our shareholders for well beyond this decade.

ARUN JAYARAM: Got you. Next question regarding Guyana is just kind of Phase 3 of the project. The country just went through, call it, an extended election cycle. There was a change of regime. And I think during that election process, the whole government, call it, suspended approval of projects such as Payara, but where do we stand? Can you talk about any discussions with the new government? And any thoughts on when we could kind of move forward with, call it, formal approval and FID of Phase 3 of these projects? Also, I was wondering if you can maybe highlight what your thoughts are on timing. I know that you and Exxon indicated the potential 6-plus-month delay just given COVID and other factors, but maybe give us an update to the market this morning or this afternoon...

JOHN B. HESS: No, the newly sitting government, President Ali, Vice President Jagdeo, have been very constructive in working with the joint venture. We're in constant communication about the approval of the production license for Payara. We're optimistic that we will get the approval of the production license before the end of the month. So I would say it's a very constructive, collaborative relationship. I think they realize that the more our joint venture can invest in the oil and gas industry in their country, the more the revenues for share prosperity of all Guyanese citizens will increase, and it's our mutual interest to move forward with the investment. So I would say all the talks are very constructive and also encouraging to get that production license approved before the end of the month.

ARUN JAYARAM: End of the month. Great. Great to hear that. One of the positive surprises, John, regarding -- going back to Phase 1, is the consortium, I think, was able to deliver that project at more than a 20% discount or under budget, 21% underbudget is really unheard of or very rare in the business to have that wide a gap relative to budget. I don't know, can you give us maybe some anecdotal comments on how Phase 2 is trending and maybe some potential upside risks regarding recovery rates, capital efficiency, but regarding Guyana?

JOHN B. HESS: Yes. Well, the first ship, as you said, versus when we started, Exxon has done a masterful job reducing the cost part of it from operating efficiency, where I think to drill and complete a well, it was over $80 million, now it's under $60 million. That's savings on every well to drill and complete. So they've done a great job on drilling. But also design one, build many, there are learnings from the first ship that are going to the second ship and then ultimately, the third ship, a gas link being one of them right away, where we see, I would say, reductions in capital costs anticipated for Liza Phase 2 as well, just like we had it for Liza Phase 1.

We're also at the low point of the cost cycle offshore, obviously, with very little activity going on globally. So that benefits us in the FPSO that benefits us on the top side, that benefits us at subsea and drilling. So across the board, we're seeing cost reduction on Liza Phase 2, almost similar to what we saw on Liza Phase 1. And Exxon is a world-class project manager, and they continue to deliver these projects below the budgeted amount.

ARUN JAYARAM: Great. John, I think we have time for 2 more questions, but I didn't want to ask you about the exploration side. And I think we could probably devote an entire Zoom conference call on the exciting exploration potential on Stabroek and beyond that because you do have a lot of leasehold within Guyana and Suriname. But can you talk firstly about the remaining exploration potential just on the Stabroek Block today?

JOHN B. HESS: Yes. As I've said before, we're still in the early innings. We've had 18 discoveries as we've correlated those well logs to seismic. We're actually seeing more opportunities. Usually, you look at the seismic for a direct hydrocarbon indicator. We're starting to see there's so many sand channels where the direct hydrocarbon indicator is maybe dimmer, which would indicate that maybe there is an oil in the sand, and we're finding that there is oil in the sand. So we're seeing a lot more running room at 15,000 feet for Campanian. Early days, we only have 2 penetrations in the Santonian at 18,000 feet. So that's why we want to bring the fifth rig in theater to get after those exploration opportunities.

Obviously, right now, we have to do so much to get the development drilling underway. We're building up a pretty good inventory that will drill next year on exploration opportunities. I would say, by the end of the year, there's a prospect outboard of Liza called Hassa. That will be one that we drill. We're currently drilling the on the Kaieteur Block that's directly north of Stabroek, our first well, the Tanager well. And also, as you know, Hess has a pretty healthy inventory of exploration opportunities and acreage in Suriname on Block 42 that's contiguous to the Apache discoveries and also Block 59. We have 1/3 interest in both of those.

And also, let's not forget, the Gulf of Mexico still has a lot of prospectivity, and they're either tieback opportunities, Miocene opportunities or Cretaceous opportunities that we'll be drilling over the next several years as cash flow permits. So the Hess inventory of upside to exploration is still very significant.

ARUN JAYARAM: Okay. John, we're going to end with 2 questions from the investors who are participating in the conference that have been sent to me. And so I'm just going to read this off to you. John, are you able to expand on your general strategy on hedging? And are the actions you took in 2020 indicative of a longer-term strategy or response to COVID-19? And any thoughts about your hedging strategy in '21 and beyond?

JOHN B. HESS: Right. Oil is a volatile commodity. It goes up, it goes down. And when it goes down, it really impedes our company and all oil companies' cash flow to fund through the cycle. The oil that is exposed for Hess is our U.S. production because the good news in the tax royalty regime, we do really well when prices are up, and you get killed when prices are down. We want to take that downside risk off the table. It's about risk management. So you can assume, as I said before, as we get to the end of the year, we will put more put options on for downside protection for the company in terms of risk management of the price risk for the company on the oil side. And you can assume in future years, we will continue to hedge year-by-year on a similar basis.

ARUN JAYARAM: Great, John. And my last question -- or pardon me, an investor question is on the surprising question that I'm sure you get a lot in the U.S., is what are John's views on the U.S. election and potential risk assuming Vice President Biden is elected as President, comma -- or question mark. And secondly, what are his thoughts if Trump is reelected? So again, John, what are your thoughts, if Biden is elected, the impact to Hess Energy, or under a Trump second term is the question from...

JOHN B. HESS: As the saying goes, it's always dangerous to talk about politics at the dinner table. It's probably dangerous to talk about it at an investor conference. With that -- and with that as a proviso, look, Vice President Biden obviously has climate change as a major item on his agenda, just like President Obama had. Specifically, what does that mean in policy, I don't think has been clarified with specifics yet, certainly as a clean energy plan to have a $2 trillion program to make the electricity 100% renewable by 2035 in the United States. That's very ambitious, given that renewable energy currently is 15% of electricity generation. So the specifics on that, we need to learn more about, how can we afford it, how can we make sure that energy costs stay controlled and reasonable for working class families. But that's one of the issues that's out there that we need to come to closure on, to have a plus-benefit analysis to have the right landing point.

In addition to that, in the debates, Vice President Biden said, there will be no new fracking. There's no such thing as no new fracking. There isn't old fracking. It's fracking. And he's walked back on that because that would have a major impact. And it would be a bad idea for the U.S. as it recovers because oil and gas are key to jobs, 12 million jobs direct and indirect, key to low energy costs for consumers and working class families and key to our national security as we're energy-independent. So that comment has been walked back to where, well, maybe we'll have no new fracking on federal lands. What we need to realize is federal lands for oil are 23% of oil supply, oil production in the country; 2/3 offshore, basically the Gulf of Mexico; 1/3 onshore.

So again, I think we're in the campaign mode. Once the president is elected, if it is Biden, I think, industry and government are going to have to work together to have some cost-benefit analysis and find a middle ground on what makes sense for energy, but also what makes sense for climate. It goes back to what I said before. You have to have climate literacy and energy literacy for sustainable development of our economy as well as the world economy. And right now, I think Biden's policies are not that specific or clear outside of the renewable and issue there for electric generation.

Obviously, President Trump has been very supportive of the oil and gas industry, streamlining regulations. So we still protect the environment, but also encouraging investment, both in the exploration and production space as well as infrastructure. So obviously, if he is reelected, I think the policies will continue to be very supportive of the business.

In either case, the United States is going to need oil and gas investment. And I think to being successful in the volatile commodity price world that we're in, the key is having the right rocks for the right returns. We're in that position, and we're going to keep our cash position and balance sheet strong, deleverage and get to that long-term strategy deliverable, which is compounding cash flow and free cash flow, that after we pay off some of our debt, we're in a position to grow our resource and grow free cash flow to return the majority of that free cash flow to our shareholders through a dividend and then complement that with share repurchases.

ARUN JAYARAM: John, on behalf of the JPMorgan team, we certainly appreciate you participating in today's fireside chat. We covered a lot of great ground today. And again, thanks for your support for the conference, and again, thanks.

JOHN B. HESS: Arun, thanks for including us and the honor of presenting and also your support and interest in the company. It's been a pleasure. Thank you.

ARUN JAYARAM: Great.

urn:contentItem:5S7G-K2C1-JCSJ-11CW-00000-00'Het wordt alleen hopeloos als je stopt met proberen';MARGRETHE VESTAGER STRIJDT OM DE VRIJE ECONOMIE TE REDDEN VAN DE DIGITALE TITANEN2018-05-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:58ZLexisNexisBlz. 8'Het wordt alleen hopeloos als je stopt met proberen'MARGRETHE VESTAGER STRIJDT OM DE VRIJE ECONOMIE TE REDDEN VAN DE DIGITALE TITANENJozef Vangelder

Suite de l'article

Suite de l'article

Big Tech palmde eerst de markt in en daarna onze privacy. Maar in Europa is de speeltijd voorbij, daar helpt Margrethe Vestager mee voor te zorgen. De Europese commissaris voor Mededinging legde al Google en andere digitale reuzen over de knie. Zij horen de economie te helpen, niet te verknechten. "Voor zakenmensen zal het klinken als een paradox: om economisch potentieel te ontketenen, heb je regulering nodig."

Weinig Europese commissarissen zijn zo bezongen geweest als Margrethe Vestager. De Deense domineedochter geldt als ongedwongen en doortastend tegelijk. Haalde ze als Deens minister soms haar breinaalden boven tijdens ministerraden, dan pakt ze als Europees commissaris voor Mededinging met evenveel gemak giganten als Apple, Google en Facebook aan.

Wanneer we Margrethe Vestager ontmoeten, heeft Mark Zuckerberg net zijn historische kruisverhoor in het Amerikaanse Congres achter de rug. De Facebook-baas moest er uitleggen hoe de persoonsgegevens op zijn servers in de verkeerde handen terecht konden komen. Miljoenen Facebook-gebruikers speelden ongewild mee in manipulatie van verkiezingen en andere duistere spelletjes. Als een miljardenbedrijf als Facebook zijn data niet kan beschermen, wie dan wel?

Voor Europa kon het Facebook-schandaal op geen beter moment komen. Deze maand treden de nieuwe Europese privacyregels in werking, de GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation). Waar de Verenigde Staten achteroplopen, kan de Europese Unie zich als een voorloper profileren, voor een keer. Nog niet lang geleden was digitale privacy iets voor oude mensen, maar het tij keert snel en de EU is bij de les. "We zijn vooruitgelopen op de curve", zegt Vestager niet zonder voldoening.

Met digitale rechten voor de consument doet Europa wat het moet doen. Zelfregulering was geen optie meer voor de machtige Big Tech-bedrijven. "Je mag niet afhankelijk zijn van goede wil", zegt Vestager, die in haar thuisland Denemarken tot de sociaal liberalen behoort. "We hebben de regulering nodig, niet door het Facebook-schandaal, maar wegens de complete machteloosheid van mensen bij pagina's en pagina's gebruiksvoorwaarden. Uiteraard vinken ze dan het blokje 'I accept' aan."

Afgezien van privacy, zien sommigen geen probleem. Bedrijven als Facebook en Google domineren de markt, maar ze bieden ook gratis diensten tegen goede kwaliteit. Zolang de consument er wel bij vaart, hoeft de overheid niet in te grijpen, luidt het.

MARGRETHE VESTAGER. "Als een bedrijf geen concurrenten heeft, zal het dan blijven innoveren voor het goed van de consument? En dat is niet het enige probleem. In veel landen is Google zowat de enige toegangspoort tot het internet geworden. Als een klein, innovatief bedrijf niet te vinden is in de zoekresultaten, hoe kan het dan de aandacht trekken van investeerders? De markt kan alleen de consument dienen bij voldoende concurrentie. Want dan is er druk om te innoveren, om het beste te bieden tegen competitieve prijzen."

Dus de concurrentie komt het eerst, daarna zien we wel of de consument aan zijn trekken komt.

VESTAGER. "De consument moet toch een keuze hebben? Als een dominant bedrijf hem die keuze ontzegt, kan je dat toch geen concurrentie noemen? Neem de zaak Google Shopping (de prijsvergelijkingsdienst van Google, door Vestager beboet met 2,4 miljard euro wegens misbruik van marktdominantie, nvdr). Google zet zijn prijsvergelijker op de eerste pagina, recht voor uw ogen. Concurrerende prijsvergelijkingsdiensten verschijnen gemiddeld pas op pagina vier van de zoekresultaten. Dan is er geen sprake van keuze. Niemand gaat naar pagina vier."

Als zoekmachine heeft Google zijn dominantie niet gestolen, maar opgebouwd met knowhow. Mag het daarvan de vruchten niet plukken?

VESTAGER. "Ik zou u volledig gelijk geven als Google 25 procent van de zoekmarkt had. Maar Google heeft 95 procent van de markt."

Maar is dat de fout van Google? Het bedrijf kan toch moeilijk zelf de concurrentie organiseren.

VESTAGER. "Neen, marktdominantie is toegelaten. Een bedrijf mag succes boeken in Europa. Maar je mag die dominantie niet misbruiken om concurrenten op afstand te houden. Marktdominantie brengt verantwoordelijkheid met zich. We controleren nu of Google die verantwoordelijkheid opneemt en concurrerende prijsvergelijkers dezelfde kansen geeft als Google Shopping."

Voert u geen strijd van het verleden? Misschien wordt Google morgen al omvergeduwd door een start-up met een betere technologie, blockchain bijvoorbeeld.

VESTAGER. "Ja, als die start-up tenminste aan bod mag komen. Als hij niet eens de kans krijgt zijn innovatie te tonen aan de markt, hoe kan hij dan bedrijven omverduwen? Het wordt moeilijk concurreren als uitvinders in hun spreekwoordelijke garage moeten blijven. De digitalisering van de economie maakt gelijke kansen des te belangrijker. Landbouw, transport, gezondheidszorg: alles digitaliseert. Ook verkopen almaar meer kmo's via een onlineplatform (zoals Amazon, nvdr). Het is de feitelijke voordeur van hun winkel geworden. Veel bedrijven zien die voordeur plots gesloten worden, zonder uitleg, zodat klanten hen niet meer kunnen vinden."

Het platform is de markt geworden en ook daar moet het spel eerlijk gespeeld worden.

VESTAGER. "Precies. Over enkele weken leggen we daartoe maatregelen op tafel. Je moet altijd oppassen voor overregulering, zeker bij fenomenen die nog in volle ontwikkeling zijn. Maar zonder regels regeert de wet van de jungle. En de jungle geeft geen tien bedrijven met elk 10 procent van de markt, de jungle geeft monopolies."

Je kunt monopolies ook van onderuit te lijf gaan, zeggen economen. Zorg gewoon dat consumenten hun data kunnen verkopen, aan meerdere bedrijven en meerdere keren in de tijd. Dan hoeven nieuwe marktspelers minder op te boksen tegen de immense databestanden van Big Tech. Wat vindt u daarvan?

VESTAGER. "Consumenten verkopen hun data nu al, voor niks. Of tenminste, ze krijgen zoekresultaten in ruil, of ze mogen tweeten. In feite geven ze Big Tech een gratis licentie voor het gebruik van hun data. Door de GDPR zal dat veranderen. Je krijgt rechten over jouw data, wat het mogelijk maakt die data te verzilveren. In enkele lidstaten duiken nu al initiatieven op, digitale assistenten die je helpen met het beheer van je privacy en de verkoop van je data."

Met een beetje geluk ontstaat een compleet nieuwe economische sector.

VESTAGER. "Het potentieel van data is enorm. We zullen ziektes uit de wereld kunnen helpen waarvoor vroeger geen behandeling was, we zullen vlot verkeer krijgen waar voordien files stonden, en veel meer. Maar dat zal pas lukken als we eerst de duistere kant van data aanpakken, als bijvoorbeeld verkiezingen niet langer gemanipuleerd worden op basis van ontfutselde persoonsgegevens. Als iedereen te bang wordt ook maar iets over zichzelf prijs te geven wegens de akelige gevolgen, dan zal het potentieel van data nooit naar boven komen. Voor zakenmensen zal het klinken als een paradox: om economisch potentieel te ontketenen, heb je regulering nodig."

Is Big Tech niet te ingewikkeld geworden voor adequate regulering? Amazon is een webwinkel, een logistiek netwerk, een cloudbedrijf en nog veel meer. De ene activiteit is een hefboom onder de andere. De concurrenten van Amazon zijn vaak tegelijk zijn klanten. Kunt u dat nog behappen?

VESTAGER. "Bedrijven met elkaar versterkende activiteiten zijn niks nieuws. De digitale tijden veranderen ook niet de motieven achter machtsmisbruik, zoals hebzucht en machtshonger. We hebben daarom geen nieuwe regels nodig maar modern gereedschap, in de vorm van hedendaagse IT. En daar investeren we ook in. In het dossier-Google moesten mijn mensen zich door 5,2 terabyte data werken. Zonder de gepast soft- en hardware lukt dat niet. Het doet bedrijven zelfs teruggrijpen naar de ouderwetse methodes. Afspraken over prijzen en de verdeling van de markt worden weer gemaakt op het golfterrein en niet langer in de cloud, waar wij ze nu kunnen vinden."

Marktdominantie is niet alleen een zaak van de digitale wereld. Volgens onderzoek is er ook een groeiend probleem in de traditionele sectoren, althans in de Verenigde Staten. Gaat het in Europa dezelfde kant op?

VESTAGER. "Dat is inderdaad ons aanvoelen. Om dat echt te besluiten, hebben we nog onvoldoende data. We hebben al data sinds de financiële crisis van 2008, en die wijzen op een toenemende concentratie in de Europese IT- en telecomsector. In dezelfde periode steeg ook het aandeel van de bedrijfswinsten in het bruto binnenlands product van 8 naar 12 procent. Dat lijkt niet veel, maar het is wel een stijging van 50 procent in een korte periode. Dat suggereert een toenemende marktmacht van bedrijven, die zo een groter deel van de koek voor zich kunnen houden, in plaats van de koek te delen met de consumenten."

U moet de concurrentie bewaken. Is het niet even belangrijk de concurrentie te stimuleren, door het inperken van lobbying bijvoorbeeld? Kleine bedrijven kunnen geen lobbyisten betalen.

VESTAGER. "Wij zijn er juist om de belangen van kleine bedrijven te bewaken. Concurrentie zorgt ervoor dat de winsten niet terechtkomen bij een select kransje bedrijven. Bij de overname van Monsanto door Bayer zorgen wij ervoor dat de boer nog altijd kan kiezen uit dezelfde hoeveelheid leveranciers van zaaigoed en onkruidverdelgers, zodat er concurrentie blijft bestaan."

Is lobbying een probleem in de Europese wandelgangen? Je hoort allerlei verhalen, zoals gekonkelfoes bij beslissingen over hormoonverstoorders of emissienormen voor auto's.

VESTAGER. "Er gaat almaar meer geld naar lobbying. Bedrijven moeten dus wel denken dat het werkt. Er is een reden waarom sommigen investeren in lobbying. Wij maken de zaken zo transparant mogelijk. Ik doe mijn best om geen lobbyisten te ontmoeten. Als mijn collega's een ontmoeting hebben met een lobbyist, komt dat in een register, zodat dat zichtbaar wordt."

De EU heeft het niet gemakkelijk. Toen de kloof tussen noord en zuid wat minder diep leek, kwam er een nieuwe kloof, tussen oost en west. Wordt het niet stilaan hopeloos?

VESTAGER. "Het wordt alleen hopeloos als je stopt met proberen. Niets is ooit verworven. Het kan altijd weer verkeerd gaan. De Europese democratie zal alleen werken als we ze gebruiken voor het goed van de mensen. Europa moet concrete problemen oplossen, het liefst van Europese of zelfs wereldwijde schaal. Wij, Denen, hebben niet de minste illusie dat we op eigen houtje de Europese grenzen kunnen beveiligen, of de opwarming van de aarde te lijf kunnen gaan. We moeten alleen oppassen dat Europa niet in een zeepbel terechtkomt. Neem die discussies over - hoe heet het ook al weer - 'interinstitutionele relaties'. Natuurlijk vragen mensen dan of we niks beters te doen hebben. Want in dat geval zijn we enkel met de interne keuken bezig."

De hervorming van de euro is geen interne keuken, helaas. Daar blijft maar hommeles over bestaan.

VESTAGER. "Conflict brengt verandering. Weinig belangrijke dingen ontstaan uit harmonie. Je weet hoe het gaat met grote politieke beslissingen: eerst zijn er heftige discussies, gevolgd door pauzes en daarna nieuwe onderhandelingen, tot de tijd eindelijk is rijp voor een compromis. In Denemarken zijn we zo blij met de Grote Beltbrug, tussen de eilanden Funen en Seeland. Het heeft ons 100 jaar gekost om te beslissen. Nu vraagt iedereen zich af waarom we de brug niet eerder hebben gebouwd."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W9Y-MDM1-DXVP-V1B7-00000-00Hewitt: To regulate Big Tech, we need prudence, not politics2019-06-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:58ZLexisNexisOPINIONHewitt: To regulate Big Tech, we need prudence, not politicsHugh Hewitt

What changed over the weekend?

Last week, the American public was generally unprepared for state-actor attacks on our cyberinfrastructure. Indeed, many Americans were generally unaware that such threats exist, even though these threats could potentially be more destructive to the country than Sept. 11, 2001, or Pearl Harbor.

Last week, U.S. social media - indeed, worldwide social media - remained open to manipulation by malign agents of disinformation. We are still defended by only the thinnest of lines at the Pentagon and within the law enforcement and intelligence communities.

Last week, our tech titans were a largely unregulated group. If not exactly indifferent to the growing consensus that these members of Big Tech are achieving dangerous concentrations of power and wealth, then at best the companies moved at a snail's pace to convince the public of their good and fair intentions and thus cut off ham-handed and outdated regulation.

Then, on Monday, reports confirmed that the Federal Trade Commission, the Justice Department and the House Judiciary Committee were launching almost simultaneous offensives against everything represented by the term "FAANG" - Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix and Google. (Disclosure: I own only Amazon stock, and The Washington Post is owned by Amazon's founder and CEO, Jeff Bezos. My views on this issue long predate either purchase.)

Neither investors nor consumers should be amused. There isn't any indication that any of the would-be regulators have the background to assess the new issues set or, crucially, even care much about the national security implications of either our collective defenses or lack of export controls on our technologies.

No notice. No public discussion. Just a bum's rush to regulate. Slow down.

I've argued for a new regulatory regime for Big Tech for years: to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., and House GOP leaders, to Federal Communications Commission Chairman Ajit Pai and national security adviser John Bolton, and to many others in both houses of Congress. About the only thing Hillary Clinton and I agreed on in our long on-air conversation after the publication of her campaign memoir was the need for everyone to read a different book ("World Without Mind," by Franklin Foer) on the dangers of the new age of artificial intelligence. I don't need to be convinced that there are risks as enormous as an unregulated Manhattan Project out there in the wilds of Big Tech."

But count me very skeptical that these risks are best addressed and remedied by FTC regulators and lawyers using statutory authorities only remotely connected to the massive problem, or by Justice Department litigators wielding theories of antitrust law that were previously not widely aired, much less debated. There's little danger posed by the newly announced congressional hearings - perhaps even some good. But the suddenness of the collective lurch against Big Tech served most to illuminate how little has been done before to ask what these new technologies are doing to us and exposing us to.

What is needed, believe it or not, is a select commission. Yes, really: It's the hoariest of old Beltway ruses for doing nothing, but this time it could do immense good. Attorney General William Barr is the right official who ought to impanel a select commission of, say, 15 or so, including the principals or general counsels of three or four of the biggest tech titans, a similar number of the country's best legal minds, senior military thinkers and a dash of academic genius and public intellectuals. Give them six months to a year to provide a comprehensive assessment of risks and regulatory approaches.

Barr knows that the government rushing in without a plan is in fact a plan for massive and potentially disastrous unintended consequences. It may indeed be that the Justice Department's antitrust division is from where the fashioning of new rules must proceed, or the export control experts at the Treasury Department, or perhaps a new regulatory structure recommended to and enacted by Congress. But this sudden spilling onto the floor of a boiling pot of unknown ingredients and enforcement actions is terrible policy.

Some thinking first, please. It is a problem of immeasurable consequence. Prudence, not politics, is required.

Hugh Hewitt, a Post contributing columnist, hosts a nationally syndicated radio show and is author of "The Fourth Way: The Conservative Playbook for a Lasting GOP Majority."

U.S. social media — indeed, worldwide social media — remained open to manipulation by malign agents of disinformation. We are still defended by only the thinnest of lines at the Pentagon and within the law enforcement and intelligence communities.

Our tech titans were a largely unregulated group. If not exactly indifferent to the growing consensus that these members of Big Tech are achieving dangerous concentrations of power and wealth, then at best the companies moved at a snail's pace to convince the public of their good and fair intentions and thus cut off ham-handed and outdated regulation.

Neither investors nor consumers should be amused. There isn't any indication any of the would-be regulators have the background to assess the new issues or even care much about the national security implications of either our collective defenses or lack of export controls on our technologies.

No notice. No public discussion. Just a bum's rush to regulate. Slow down.

I've argued for a new regulatory regime for Big Tech for years: to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., and House GOP leaders, to Federal Communications Commission Chairman Ajit Pai and national security adviser John Bolton, and to many others in both houses of Congress. About the only thing Hillary Clinton and I agreed on in our long on-air conversation after the publication of her campaign memoir was the need for everyone to read a different book ("World Without Mind," by Franklin Foer) on the dangers of the new age of artificial intelligence. I don't need to be convinced there are risks as enormous as an unregulated Manhattan Project out there in the wilds of Big Tech."

But count me skeptical that these risks are best addressed and remedied by FTC regulators and lawyers using statutory authorities only remotely connected to the problem, or by Justice Department litigators wielding theories of antitrust law that were not widely aired, much less debated. There's little danger posed by the newly announced congressional hearings — perhaps even some good. But the suddenness of the collective lurch against Big Tech served most to illuminate how little has been done before to ask what these new technologies are doing to us and exposing us to.

What is needed, believe it or not, is a select commission. Yes, really: It's the hoariest of old Beltway ruses for doing nothing, but this time it could do immense good. Attorney General William Barr is the right official who ought to impanel a select commission of, say, 15 or so, including the principals or general counsels of three or four of the biggest tech titans, a similar number of the country's best legal minds, senior military thinkers and a dash of academic genius and public intellectuals. Give them six months to a year to provide a comprehensive assessment of risks and regulatory approaches.

Barr knows the government rushing in without a plan is in fact a plan for massive and potentially disastrous unintended consequences. It may indeed be that the Justice Department's antitrust division is from where the fashioning of new rules must proceed, or the export control experts at the Treasury Department, or perhaps a new regulatory structure recommended to and enacted by Congress. But this sudden spilling onto the floor of a boiling pot of unknown ingredients and enforcement actions is terrible policy.

Some thinking first, please. It is a problem of immeasurable consequence. Prudence, not politics, is required.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W9T-0MT1-JBCN-412X-00000-00Hewitt: To regulate Big Tech, we need prudence, not politics2019-06-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:58ZLexisNexisOPINIONHewitt: To regulate Big Tech, we need prudence, not politicsHugh Hewitt

What changed over the weekend?

Last week, the American public was generally unprepared for state-actor attacks on our cyberinfrastructure. Indeed, many Americans were generally unaware that such threats exist, even though these threats could potentially be more destructive to the country than Sept. 11, 2001, or Pearl Harbor.

Last week, U.S. social media - indeed, worldwide social media - remained open to manipulation by malign agents of disinformation. We are still defended by only the thinnest of lines at the Pentagon and within the law enforcement and intelligence communities.

Last week, our tech titans were a largely unregulated group. If not exactly indifferent to the growing consensus that these members of Big Tech are achieving dangerous concentrations of power and wealth, then at best the companies moved at a snail's pace to convince the public of their good and fair intentions and thus cut off ham-handed and outdated regulation.

Then, on Monday, reports confirmed that the Federal Trade Commission, the Justice Department and the House Judiciary Committee were launching almost simultaneous offensives against everything represented by the term "FAANG" - Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix and Google. (Disclosure: I own only Amazon stock, and The Washington Post is owned by Amazon's founder and CEO, Jeff Bezos. My views on this issue long predate either purchase.)

Neither investors nor consumers should be amused. There isn't any indication that any of the would-be regulators have the background to assess the new issues set or, crucially, even care much about the national security implications of either our collective defenses or lack of export controls on our technologies.

No notice. No public discussion. Just a bum's rush to regulate. Slow down.

I've argued for a new regulatory regime for Big Tech for years: to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., and House GOP leaders, to Federal Communications Commission Chairman Ajit Pai and national security adviser John Bolton, and to many others in both houses of Congress. About the only thing Hillary Clinton and I agreed on in our long on-air conversation after the publication of her campaign memoir was the need for everyone to read a different book ("World Without Mind," by Franklin Foer) on the dangers of the new age of artificial intelligence. I don't need to be convinced that there are risks as enormous as an unregulated Manhattan Project out there in the wilds of Big Tech."

But count me very skeptical that these risks are best addressed and remedied by FTC regulators and lawyers using statutory authorities only remotely connected to the massive problem, or by Justice Department litigators wielding theories of antitrust law that were previously not widely aired, much less debated. There's little danger posed by the newly announced congressional hearings - perhaps even some good. But the suddenness of the collective lurch against Big Tech served most to illuminate how little has been done before to ask what these new technologies are doing to us and exposing us to.

What is needed, believe it or not, is a select commission. Yes, really: It's the hoariest of old Beltway ruses for doing nothing, but this time it could do immense good. Attorney General William Barr is the right official who ought to impanel a select commission of, say, 15 or so, including the principals or general counsels of three or four of the biggest tech titans, a similar number of the country's best legal minds, senior military thinkers and a dash of academic genius and public intellectuals. Give them six months to a year to provide a comprehensive assessment of risks and regulatory approaches.

Barr knows that the government rushing in without a plan is in fact a plan for massive and potentially disastrous unintended consequences. It may indeed be that the Justice Department's antitrust division is from where the fashioning of new rules must proceed, or the export control experts at the Treasury Department, or perhaps a new regulatory structure recommended to and enacted by Congress. But this sudden spilling onto the floor of a boiling pot of unknown ingredients and enforcement actions is terrible policy.

Some thinking first, please. It is a problem of immeasurable consequence. Prudence, not politics, is required.

Hugh Hewitt, a Post contributing columnist, hosts a nationally syndicated radio show and is author of "The Fourth Way: The Conservative Playbook for a Lasting GOP Majority."

Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company - VP & General Manager of Japan Pointnext

* Peter J. Ungaro

Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company - General Manager of High Performance Computing (HPC) & Mission Critical Solutions (MCS)

* Ted Dunning

Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company - Data Fabric Technologist

Conference Call Participants

* Bill Graff

Cerner Corporation - Chief Information Officer

* Crawford Del Prete

IDC UK Ltd. - Chief Research Officer and EVP of Worldwide Research Products

* Daisy McAndrew

- Journalist

* Debbie Hubbard

Nationwide Building Society - Technical Service Manager

* Dennis Nobelius

Zenuity AB - CEO

* Jeremiah Owyang

Kaleido Insights - Industry Analyst & Founding Partner

* John Chambers

JC2 Ventures - Founder and CEO

* Sally Eaves

Forbes Technology Council - Official Member

* Susan G. Middleton

International Data Corporation - Research Director for Technology Financing Strategies

* Tanja Vainio

Impact Coatings AB (publ) - Independent Director

* Tim Stenovec

Cheddar - Anchor

Presentation

DAISY MCANDREW, JOURNALIST: Well, hello, and a very warm welcome to the Hewlett Packard Enterprise Discover Virtual Experience. I'm Daisy McAndrew.

TIM STENOVEC, ANCHOR, CHEDDAR: And I'm Tim Stenovec. To say that this HPE Discover is like no other is an understatement. The state of the world, amid a global pandemic, has changed everything, and it's hit very close to home for HPE.

DAISY MCANDREW: Well, it certainly has, Tim, because HPE's CEO, Antonio Neri, himself recently shared that he tested positive for COVID-19. But I am so pleased to say that Antonio is able to join us today to talk about all that's ahead for this HPE Discover Virtual Experience. Antonio, before we talk business, I know the entire community, including myself, really wants to know, how are you feeling?

ANTONIO FABIO NERI, CEO, PRESIDENT & DIRECTOR, HEWLETT PACKARD ENTERPRISE COMPANY: Well, first of all, hi, Daisy, and thanks for having me today. I feel much better. I'm now into the second week, and I have to say I feel pretty much back to normal. Obviously, the first few days were a little bit more difficult where you're tired, you're lightheaded. But I feel much better, ready to go for the week ahead, which is a very exciting week as a part of our HPE Discover, which this year is a virtual experience, and you will see we are raising the bar once again.

DAISY MCANDREW: Certainly raising the bar. And so many changes. Antonio, we've got your keynote coming right up in just a moment. I'm so glad you're well enough to bring that to attendees. What can we expect to hear from you?

ANTONIO FABIO NERI: Well, as always, we want to come across as the best partner for our customers to work. We listen to them. We understand their needs. And we're going to demonstrate the progress we have made in the last year. As you recall, last year, I said that we're going to make everything we do in this company available as a service by 2022. So I'm going to provide an insight into that. And with a series of announcements, which are very exciting, around the cloud services and our software portfolio. We'll also talk about the -- a new age of insight, is a new area we are entering. And I have asked my dear friend, John Chambers, to talk about this, because even in the pandemic, we see that the opportunities continue to grow tremendously. And we believe we need to move from collecting data to providing insight to the business. And John and I have a unique point of view. I'm sure the audience will enjoy hearing from John how we think about the future.

DAISY MCANDREW: I'm sure you're right, Antonio. We look forward to hearing more from you in your keynote.

ANTONIO FABIO NERI: Well, thank you for covering us this week, and I hope to speak to you throughout the event. Take care.

DAISY MCANDREW: Antonio, you, too. All right, Tim. Well, as they say, let's get on with the show.

TIM STENOVEC: Thanks, Daisy. It is so great to hear from Antonio. And by going virtual, HPE has managed to make Discover into a more global, yet more intimate experience for people around the world. It's going to be a great couple of days.

DAISY MCANDREW: Tim, you're so right. 150 sessions coming right to you, the attendee, live and on demand. You consume the content HPE will provide at your own pace. You choose your own adventure, if you like. Now all of the things you've come to expect and look forward to from past Discover events are still available. The sessions, the demos, training, the HP leaders, industry experts and customers, all available to you in this new virtual experience. So HPE has even managed to bring a little bit of Vegas to this event. What do I mean? Well, you know Vegas never shuts down and neither does this, the HPE Discover Virtual event. This Discover is always on with live programming to accommodate any time zone in the world with a wealth of on-demand content available in your own time anytime.

TIM STENOVEC: A special thank you today to customers and partners. Just by registering, you've helped in the fight against COVID-19. Each registration for Discover Virtual Experience translated into a $10 donation on behalf of HPE to 1 of the 10 charities in the fight against COVID as the company lives up to its purpose of advancing the way people live and work.

DAISY MCANDREW: That's such great stuff, Tim. And thank you, of course. Now as an IT leader on the front lines during the COVID pandemic, and as we make our way forward in the digital transformation that's become mission-critical for businesses today, HPE is here to help. In 2020, the success of businesses around the globe won't be judged on earnings or stock prices. This year will be all about how enterprises stepped up in society or in support of their employees as COVID-19 swept the globe and life became remote.

Now, of course, the tech industry was front and center in a movement known as Tech for Good. And I'm really thrilled to be joined now by tech industry leader, Sally Eaves, to talk about the role the industry needs to play in the rebuilding of work and the rebuilding of societies in a post COVID-19 world. Sally, a very warm welcome. I want to start off by asking you, does the tech industry have a responsibility to -- I know it sounds like a cliché, but make the world a better place? And if it does, how?

SALLY EAVES, OFFICIAL MEMBER, FORBES TECHNOLOGY COUNCIL: Firstly, wholeheartedly, yes. As you know, Tech for Good is a massive passion of mine, and it's not something just to be spoken about. It's something that we have to do. It must be actualized. And I think COVID-19 is a tipping point moment for Tech for Good. We've seen how we can come together. We've seen how we must come together, and tech could be a massive force, not just for digital transformation for business and for business continuity to keep business going, but much more than that. It can make a pivotal difference for society as well. So we've seen this tipping point moment. I think the high-performance computing consortium is one great example of that. The tech industry coming together, 11 different tech companies, an ethos, a collaboration above competition and working together hand-in-hand with a variety of different other organizations, especially education, especially academia, closing the gaps.

Now we've seen innovation, for example, around vaccines and pharmaceuticals would normally have taken, say, 15 to 18 months. We've seen huge strides in 7 weeks. That's unprecedented. But we've also seen, over this period of time, digital equity gaps. We have to close them. But, again, we've seen tech companies stepping up to the plate in 24 hours coming out to schools, setting up WiFi systems in car parks, doing all sorts of things at very short notice and being very pragmatic at times as well, but it's been about that doing. So I think now Tech for Good is becoming embedded in everything that we do. And I'm -- looking ahead from COVID-19, for me, the positive legacy of this is that this is being embedded into all business models.

I've always said this, it's not an add-on. It's not an afterthought. Tech for Good should be at the heart of all we're doing as good businesses. So I think in the future, people won't be looking on return on investment. I'd like to think of it as return on social investment. And I have a real [inner] clarion call to really follow that example. And I think it's, yes, to say, tipping point moment for Tech for Good right here right now.

DAISY MCANDREW: It certainty is what you call a tipping point moment. So I think all of us realize that this is a big moment and a big moment of change. And I want to talk to you now about trust in tech and what's changing in that area. Is this an opportunity to help rebuild some of the erosion of trust that exists towards technology today, Sally?

First thing is, as a leader, you don't hide. You need to be very transparent, out in front.
